repnme.cdata!:
The Gambia - Capacity Building for Economic
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Capacity Building for
            Economic Management Project (CBEMP) for the Gambia were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: in countries with very limited public sector
            capacity, a major overhaul of public sector management
            systems on multiple fronts simultaneously is likely to
            require a programmatic approach to lending rather than a
            single investment loan. The downscaling of initiatives
            during CBEMP implementation, the additional financing and
            the extension of the closing date for the project indicate
            that the full implementation of the project initiatives
            under a single credit was unrealistic from the beginning.
            Fundamental reforms in the Government's way of doing
            business require a long term perspective. When such reforms
            are attempted under a single project, inevitably it leads to
            implementation delays and significant risks to
            sustainability due to the lack of time for the reforms to
            become entrenched. For this reason, a second CBEMP is
            currently under preparation in order to sustain and deepen
            implementation of key initiatives under the first CBEMP.
            Commitment to the project at the top levels of Government is
            a necessary but not sufficient condition for timely project
            implementation. A fully satisfactory outcome ultimately must
            have the backing of the line managers in charge of
            implementing the project's components. For CBEMP, it
            was not until there was a change in the relevant management,
            several years after the start of the project that
            substantial work on the Integrated Financial Management
            Information System (IFMIS) began in earnest. It is
            recommended that a clear and transparent mechanism be
            established in advance on how best to address instances of
            protracted lack of commitment by a beneficiary, including
            triggers for the removal of the beneficiary through project restructuring.

repnme.cdata!:
Gambia - Capacity Building for Economic
            Management Project (Additional Financing)

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Paper seeks the approval o
            f the Executive Directors to provide an additional grant to
            the Republic of The Gambia for the Capacity Building for
            Economic Management Project. The proposed additional
            financing would help finance costs associated with some of
            the original Project activities which have experienced cost
            overruns. The additional financing would allow the
            Government to complete ongoing initiatives, thereby
            contributing towards the achievement o f the Project
            Development Objective (PDO) and the sustainability of the
            initiatives. Neither an expansion nor a scale-up of the
            original Project activities are proposed. The specific
            activities to be financed are the continuation of the: (i)
            establishment of the Integrated Financial Management
            Information System (IFMIS) and building local capacity in it
            s usage; (ii) establishment of the Gambia Revenue Authority
            (GRA) and strengthening its operational capacity; and (iii)
            streamlining of customs procedures and upgrading of the
            Automated System Customs Data Administration Information
            Technology (IT) System (ASYCUDA). The expected outcomes from
            these activities are improved public financial management,
            both for revenue and expenditures. Ongoing Project
            initiatives will become more effective and sustainable due
            to strengthened local capacity.

repnme.cdata!:
Gambia - Capacity Building for Economic
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Capacity Building for Economic
            Management Project will help build the Government capacity
            for economic policy formulation, and execution, including
            capacity building of the judicial, and financial systems, to
            facilitate private sector development. Project components
            aim at: 1) strengthening macroeconomic analysis, and policy
            formulation, through the provision of technical advice to
            the Department of State for Finance and Economic Affairs
            (DOSFEA) on economic, and social policies, oversee the
            economic planning design, participate in the preparation of
            the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper, and expenditure
            reviews, and, promote consistent social, and economic
            policies, including assistance for budget implementation. To
            this end, reliable statistics are needed, based on a
            strengthened data collection on national accounts,
            employment, expenditure, and social aspects, factors which
            will be improved by building the Central Statistics
            Department's capacity, and upgrading statistical
            analysis to meet international standards; 2) strengthening
            public resource management, by restructuring the Central
            Revenue Department (CRD), to improve accountability, and
            management, and, by setting up a tax payers unit to control
            revenue collection. CRD's processes will be
            reengineered, computerization will improve tax assessments,
            while consulting services, and training will support the
            review of legal frameworks, public expenditure, and
            financial management; and, 3) facilitating private sector
            development, by building capacity, primarily on the legal,
            financial, and regulatory sectors.
